content: All of these “fun” activities are actually better seen as code language for “we have a chill + fun environment.” Alas, the reality is most of the time it isn’t a fun environment: people are overworked, uncertain about their jobs, and wondering whether fitting into the culture is actually going to mean they’ll be successful — Buffer’s great piece “Why We’ve Stopped Saying “Culture Fit” — and What We’re Saying Instead” discusses this more. Here’s what “fun at work” actually looks like: Winning with people you enjoy working with, getting paid nicely for it, being rewarded for doing a good job, and being able to have a life outside of work. No kegerator needed.
